Recursion

Recursion happens when a function calls itself. The function is called a recursive function. Recursive functions do a small part of the task in each recursive call, similar to a loop. Note: recursion and looping are not the same. Most of the time, recursion can simplify your code and make algorithms easier to understand. However, there are also some cases where using recursion makes your program confusing and inefficient.

The Three Parts of a Recursive Function

  1. A base case
  2. A recursive call on a smaller data set; and
  3. Some work at each level

When writing a recursive function, there should always be at least one base case. This is necessary to tell the function when to stop the recursion and what to do at the end of the recursive calls. For most recursive functions, this is usually done with an if statement checking to see if one of the parameters reaches a certain value. For instance, if we are recursively calculating the factorial function, we check to see if our argument is 1, in which case we just return 1, rather than making a recursive call.

Each recursive step should do a small portion of the overall task. This is similar to the body of a loop. The small portion of the task could be done before you call the function again, or afterwards.

A recursive function would, of course, have at least one recursive call. The function calls itself, but with new parameters. In general, a parameter should get closer to the base case with each recursive call so that it will eventually reach the base case. If there is a non-void return type for the function, you have to make sure you return the recursive call.

One way of writing recursive functions is to assume the function works on a smaller scale of the problem. Assuming the function does what it's supposed to on the next recursive call, what do we need to add to make it complete? For example, if we are recursively summing a data structure, and we assume the call sum(n - 1) worked, what else do we need to do? Well, add n to that sum, of course! So we would write: return n + sum(n - 1)
